thread.title: Deal parking plan limits beach access
thread.title_full: Deal parking plan limits beach access

author: app.com
title: Deal parking plan limits beach access
text:
MORE A proposal to require parking permits on six oceanfront streets in Deal has fishermen, surfers and those in favor of unfettered beach access up in arms.
The permits will be issued to borough residents only and will be required from May 1 to Oct. 31.
Because the ordinance will limit parking for non-residents, it will also restrict access to the beaches, which have been the recipient of an estimated $40 million beach replenishment project.
As the project is nearing completion, the proposed plan has raised suspicions among public access advocates as a move to limit access to the new beaches.
Since the beach replenishment project was funded by taxpayer money, one of the stipulations for funding was that it be available for use by the public and access be provided. If there is no place to park, it will make access to the wider beaches much more difficult.
The Surfrider Foundation, The American Littoral Society and fishermen's groups such as the Asbury Park Fishing Club are asking interested individuals to attend a borough meeting where arguments on the ordinance will be heard this Friday, Oct. 9, at 9 a.m at the Borough Hall, 190 Norwood Ave. in Deal.
Tuna Stakes Invitational
The Tuna Stakes Invitational, which was postponed by the wind and rain of the past weekend's nor'easter and the threat from Hurricane Joaquin, has been rescheduled for later this week.
Tournament Director Len Strobel said the Captain's Meeting will take place Tuesday, Oct. 6 from 6 to 8 p.m. at the Reel Seat in Brielle, located at 707 Union Ave. (Route 71) in Brielle.
The format for the $50,000 winner-take-all allows each entrant to fish one of the 10 available fishing days which consists of an overnight trip with lines in at 8 a.m. and lines out at 10 a.m. the following day.
For tournament updates, visit www.tunastakesinvitational.com
On the water
It's going to take a few days for the ocean to calm down after the weekend's raging wind and theof the hurricane to what kind of shape the fishing is in.
Reports for anglers have been pretty much non existent with the only one coming form Bob Matthews at Fisherman's Den in Belmar.
He said one shop regular caught a number of short bass fishing bombers in back waters out of the wind. Matthews also reported that a lot of kingfish were being taken before the blow, along with spot and small porgies. It's anybody's guess if they're still around.
John Oswald: joswald@gannettnj.com
